items.synopsis: Bob Hawke returned from the remote Northern Territory in 1988 to a divided, partisan parliament. Some say this sunk the prospect of a treaty before the idea ever got off the ground.

image.altText: Marcia Langton at a press conference in Parliament House

items.synopsis: Bunburying is the art of concocting a noble-sounding alibi to provide cover for an undisclosed and less-noble objective. Why is this relevant today? Because senior First Nations academic Marcia Langton has been at the centre of a comprehensive Bunburying. Here's what transpired, writes Annabel Crabb.

title.children: There's a foul, rising tide of racism in the Voice debate ahead of the referendum

image.altText: ASX 200 board

items.synopsis: A rally on Wall Street overnight is likely to send Australian stocks higher. Hotter-than-expected economic data in the US eased worries about a recession without raising fears of a Federal Reserve rate hike next week. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX to rise after a broad rally on Wall Street

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: New Zealand's manufacturing sector contracted again in August and is well below its long-term average, a survey showed on Friday. The Bank of New Zealand-BusinessNZ's seasonally adjusted Performance of Manufacturing Index (PMI) fell to 46.1 in August from a revised 46.6 in July. New orders edged higher to 46.6  from 45 in the prior month. A reading above 50 indicates manufacturing activity is expanding, while anything below that threshold points to contraction. The August result told the tale of another tough month for the sector, BusinessNZ's director of advocacy, Catherine Beard, said in a statement.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: NZ manufacturing sector again edges lower in August

children.content: New Zealand's manufacturing sector contracted again in August and is

The Bank of New Zealand-BusinessNZ's seasonally adjusted Performance of Manufacturing Index (PMI) fell to 46.1 in August from a revised 46.6 in July. New orders edged higher to 46.6  from 45 in the prior month.
A reading above 50 indicates manufacturing activity is expanding, while anything below that threshold points to contraction.
The August result told the tale of another tough month for the sector, BusinessNZ's director of advocacy, Catherine Beard, said in a statement.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In recent years, ticket prices have spiked globally — and not just for artists like Taylor Swift or Ed Sheeran. According to Live Performance Australia, from 2004 to 2019 the average Australian ticket price for a live performance grew from about $55 to almost $93. Similarly, in North America, the average ticket price to one of the top 100 tours grew from about $US90 ($140) to $US111 ($172) in 2022. In June, Reuters reported that the inflation for a live performance ticket in the US was 2.6 per cent higher than the country's inflation rate. And the Wall Street Journal reports the average resale price on resale platform SeatGeek grew from $US125 ($195) in 2019 to $US252 ($394) in 2023. Read more from Sam Nichols for The Money.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Live music ticket prices are skyrocketing

featuredLink.title: 'Staggering' prices and new marketing ploys: How the economics of live music is changing

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hello, Sam Yang here to take you through markets this Friday. All three major stock indexes on Wall Street ended higher, as did all 11 major sectors of the S & P 500. And it looks like the ASX will follow, with futures up more than 1 per cent. In the US, retail sales rose more than expected in August on higher gasoline prices, while initial claims for state unemployment benefits climbed to a seasonally adjusted 220,000 for the week ended September 9 from 217,000 the week before. Monthly producer prices for final demand rose 0.7 per cent last month, against expectations of a 0.4 per cent increase. On an annual basis, they increased 1.6 per cent compared with estimates of a 1.2 per cent rise. "Today's economic data confirms the path toward a soft landing, but without being so hot that the Fed thinks they might need to do a couple more rate hikes," said Ross Mayfield, Investment Strategy Analyst at Baird. "All together, it's pretty bullish." European stocks jumped to their biggest one-day percentage gain in six months, after the European Central Bank - hiking interest rates for the tenth straight time - suggested it was at the end of its monetary policy tightening cycle. The pan-European STOXX 600 rose 1.5 per cent and MSCI's gauge of stocks across the globe gained 0.8 per cent. Oil prices surged to their highest since November as a tighter supply outlook offset demand concerns. Gold prices rebounded after an initial dip in opposition to the strengthening greenback.

image.altText: Two women crouched next to a dog in a harness.

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Therapy dogs at airports as two capitals brace for biggest post-COVID travel days. The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The school holiday rush is underway at Melbourne Airport, where staff are bracing for the busiest day since the start of the pandemic. ABC Reporter Stephanie Ferrier is at Melbourne Airport this morning. "It's very congested here already, with up to 114,000 travellers expected today," she says. "Top destinations include Sydney, Brisbane, Indonesia and New Zealand. Passengers say there've been big queues at the car parks and check-in desks but they're focussed on their holidays." Meanwhile, at Brisbane Airport, therapy dogs have been brought in to help with travel stress in the crowds. Friday, September 29 is forecast to be Brisbane airport's busiest day post-COVID, with 70,000 passengers expected to past through. Domestic travel is expected to be 6 per cent busier than the same time last year, with 1,287,000 passengers forecast to travel around the country — this is 92 per cent of pre-Covid 2019 levels.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Brisbane and Melbourne airports brace for busiest days post-COVID

children.content: The school holiday rush is underway at Melbourne Airport, where staff are bracing for the busiest day since the start of the pandemic.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Chris Dawson is due to be sentenced this morning, after he was found guilty of carnal knowledge. Dawson faced a judge-alone trial in the NSW District Court, where he pleaded not guilty to one count of carnal knowledge of a girl aged between 10 and 17. He is currently serving a 24-year jail sentence after he was last year found guilty of murdering his first wife, Lynette Simms, who vanished in 1982.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian Medical Association (AMA) is holding a rural medical training summit in Canberra today in response to crippling rural workforce shortages and a lack of specialist training opportunities throughout regional Australia. AMA president Steve Robson told News Breakfast the state in the regions was "catastrophic". "Australians who live outside our capital cities understand how difficult it is to see a heart specialist, a psychiatrist, an obstetrician to have a baby," he told the program. "There are critical shortages. Australians who live in those regions can't wait any longer." Dr Robson says training will play a critical role in building a rural and regional workforce.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: AMA says regional health workforce shortages are 'catastrophic'

props.alt: A man in a suit jacket wearing glasses.

children.content: The Australian Medical Association (AMA) is holding a rural medical training summit in Canberra today in response to crippling rural workforce shortages and a lack of specialist training opportunities throughout regional Australia.
AMA president Steve Robson told News Breakfast the state in the regions was "catastrophic".
"Australians who live outside our capital cities understand how difficult it is to see a heart specialist, a psychiatrist, an obstetrician to have a baby," he told the program.
"There are critical shortages. Australians who live in those regions can't wait any longer."
Dr Robson says training will play a critical role in building a rural and regional workforce.
